title: Semicolon woes

labels.name: C-enhancement

labels.name: A-diagnostics

body:
## I tried this code: ```rust fn write_db(key: String, val: String) -> Result<(), Error> { std::fs::write( "hello.txt", format!("{} {}", key, val)); } ``` ## I expected to see this happen: Compiled successfully ## Instead, this happened: The following error message was reported by the compiler which was far from helpful: ``` error[E0308]: mismatched types --> src\main.rs:15:42 | 15 | fn write_db(key: String, val: String) -> Result<(), Error> { | -------- ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ expected enum `std::result::Result`, found `()` | | | implicitly returns `()` as its body has no tail or `return` expression ... 18 | format!("{} {}", key, val)); | - help: consider removing this semicolon | = note: expected enum `std::result::Result<(), std::io::Error>` found unit type `()` ``` To be fair, the compiler does hint that I should've removed the trailing `;` (semicolon), but one only sees this if one reads all the way through the entire error ... which isn't reported in full by tooling: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/961950/101247869-b2745d00-36d0-11eb-8aa4-a196dedbbfdc.png) So the error here isn't that there's a type mismatch; the error is that there's a trailing ; which for "reasons" returns a nil `()` expression ## A plea to the Rust team Rust is often proposed as a "better" __replacement for__ C/C++. As such, please consider the plight of C/C++ developers learning and porting large bodies of C/C++ code to Rust. While Rust shouldn't aim to be a better C/C++, please try to inform C/C++ developers where their C/C++-isms won't work, wherever possible. In fact, I'd argue that suggested fixes should come before explanations in error messages. I spent 4 hours on the issue above, reading docs, SO issues, rewrote the code 4-5 times. Checked to see if I was running the latest compiler version, installed half a dozen Rust addins for VSCode to hope that one of them could tell me what I was doing wrong, etc. At no point did I ever consider that the error was caused by a terminating semicolon! 😠 And it was all because Rust has a rule that a semicolon should suppress the result of an expression. In which case ... ```rust let foo = 2; ``` ... shouldn't set `foo` to `2` because the `;` should return the nil expression, no? Isn't this an inconsistent application of the semicolon rule? ### Meta `rustc --version --verbose`: ``` rustc 1.48.0 (7eac88abb 2020-11-16) binary: rustc commit-hash: 7eac88abb2e57e752f3302f02be5f3ce3d7adfb4 commit-date: 2020-11-16 host: x86_64-pc-windows-msvc release: 1.48.0 LLVM version: 11.0 ```
